Roberts
A3R Roberts
Don Brine | birth_name = Adam Roberts | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1965|06|30}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Academic, critic, writer | nationality = British | ethnicity = | religion = | citizenship = British | education = PhD | alma_mater = [[University of Aberdeen]]
[[Cambridge University]] | period = | genre = Science fiction, fantasy, parody | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''[[Salt (novel)|Salt]]'', ''[[Gradisil]]'', ''[[Yellow Blue Tibia]]'', ''[[By Light Alone]]'', ''Jack Glass'' | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = {{awd|award=BSFA Award for Best Novel|year=2012|title=Jack Glass}} {{awd|award=Arthur C. Clarke Award nominee|year=2001|title=[[Salt (novel)|Salt]]|role=|name=| year2=2007|title2=[[Gradisil]]|role2=}} 2010 [[Yellow Blue Tibia]] | signature = | website = {{URL|adamroberts.com}} | portaldisp = }} '''Adam Charles Roberts''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRSL}} (born 30 June 1965){{cite web |url= http://authorities.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?DB=local&PAGE=First |title=Roberts, Adam (Adam Charles) |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] Authorities |accessdate= 13 August 2012}} is a [[British people|British]] science fiction and fantasy novelist. In 2018 he was elected Vice-President of the [[H.G. Wells Society]]. ==Career== He has a [[academic degree|degree]] in [[English studies|English]] from the [[University of Aberdeen]] and a PhD from [[Cambridge University]] on [[Robert Browning]] and the Classics. He teaches [[English literature]] and [[creative writing]] at [[Royal Holloway, University of London]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/profile/adam-roberts |title=Adam Roberts |publisher=The Guardian |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2015-09-26}} Adam Roberts has been nominated three times for the [[Arthur C. Clarke Award]]: in 2001 for his [[debut novel]], ''[[Salt (novel)|Salt]]'', in 2007 for ''[[Gradisil]]'' and in 2010 for ''[[Yellow Blue Tibia]]''. He won both the 2012 [[BSFA Award for Best Novel]], and the [[John W. Campbell Memorial Award]], for ''Jack Glass''. It was further shortlisted for [[The Kitschies]] Red Tentacle award. His short story "Tollund" was nominated for the 2014 [[Sidewise Award]].{{cite news|url=http://www.locusmag.com/News/2014/06/2014-sidewise-award-finalists/ |title=2014 Sidewise Award Finalists |publisher=Locus|date=2014-06-06 |accessdate=2014-06-06}} Roberts' science fiction has been praised by many critics both inside and outside the genre, with some of the latter going so far as to describe him as being on a par with such past masters of the genre as Pel Torro, John E. Muller, and Karl Zeigfreid. In May 2014, Roberts gave the second annual [[Tolkien Lecture]] at [[Pembroke College, Oxford]], speaking on the topic of Tolkien and Women.[https://tolkienlecture.org/2014/05/14/adam-roberts-lecture-podcast-now-available/ Adam Roberts Lecture Podcast Now Available], ''The J.R.R. Tolkien Lecture on Fantasy Literature'', 14 May 2014. {{Refimprove|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox video game |title = Apidya |image = Apidya Cover.jpg |caption = Cover art of ''Apidya'' |developer = [[Kaiko GmbH|Kaiko]] |publisher = [[Play Byte]] |designer = Peter Thierolf |artist = Frank Matzke |composer = [[Chris Hülsbeck]] |released = {{vgy|1992}} |genre = [[Shoot 'em up]] |modes = [[Single-player]]
[[Multiplayer|Two-player (cooperative)]]
[[Multiplayer|Two-player (alternating)]] |platforms = [[Amiga]] }} '''Apidya''' (titled {{nihongo|'''Abidja'''|アビヂャ}} in Japanese characters below the title) is a [[Shoot 'em up#Scrolling shooters|horizontally scrolling shoot 'em up]] video game developed by [[Kaiko GmbH|Kaiko]] and released by [[Play Byte]] in 1992 for the [[Amiga]]. It was Kaiko's second game developed. Despite being labelled II in the title it is not a sequel to any game, but has the digits placed there simply for a gag. {{cite interview |title=Interview|first=Chris|last=Huelsbeck|interviewer=T.R. Schmidt|url=http://www.nemmelheim.de/kaiko/interview_e.html |date=6 July 2000 |website=Kaiko History |accessdate=24 December 2014}} ==Plot== The story revolves around Ikuro, whose wife Yuri has been poisoned by Hexaae, an evil lord of black magic. Ikuro uses magic to transform into a deadly [[bee]] and vows to find an antidote for Yuri and wreak revenge on Hexaae. ==Gameplay== The game is a horizontally scrolling shooter, with some elements similar to early, classic shoot 'em ups. The player controls a bee capable of launching a number of projectiles which can damage or destroy enemy targets. The game uses the power-up bar system pioneered by ''[[Gradius]]''. Destroyed enemies sometimes leave a power-up in the form of a red-and-yellow flower. The player may collect these flowers and activate new weapons and enhancements. A 'build-up' weapon, similar to the 'beam' weapon in ''[[R-Type]]'', also features. If the fire button is held down for a second or two, the bee produces a hissing noise and releasing the fire button will then cause the bee to fire a large, organic projectile (a giant bee sting) which can wipe out waves of small enemies, or damage larger ones. If the player's bee is hit by enemy fire or crashes into the terrain, a life will be lost and the current stage is restarted except for the end bosses of the first 3 stages, that will continue till all lives are lost. Once all lives are lost the game ends. A co-operative two-player mode is possible, in which the second player controls a smaller companion drone, which can launch small projectiles and shield the first player. The drone can sustain 5 small projectiles per life but won't survive large projectiles or collisions and the stage doesn't reset if it dies, the large bee is the alpha which must survive to advance. The alpha bee dying resets the stage as with normal play minus end stage bosses for the first 3 stages. An alternating two player mode is also possible. The game consists of five themed levels: a meadow, a pond, a sewer filled with mutated enemies, a bio-technological machine and a final level where the player must battle five final bosses. The final level offers plenty of points for slain enemies, offering a semi status quo for players as they will recover some lost lives from restarting the level. Each level is divided up into a number of stages (usually three where the last is the end boss, that doesn't reset upon losing a life only on credit). There are also a number of hidden bonus levels. In the first two levels, nearly all the enemies are real creatures which may be found in a meadow or pond. The later levels feature mutant and inorganic creations. During "Techno Party", the bee morphs into a more mechanized form for the duration of that level. The first boss is unique, it cannot be harmed so the player must survive till it vacates the game. There are four difficultly settings. When the difficulty is set to "easy", it is not possible to play the last level, the ending sequence is skipped and the player is directed straight to the end credits. ==Music== The musical soundtrack to the game was composed by game musician [[Chris Hülsbeck]]. A high-quality arrangement of the soundtrack was released as a CD album in 1992. The soundtrack of level 4 features several samples from [[L.A. Style]]'s ''[[James Brown Is Dead]]''. There have also been live performances of the game's music:{{cn|date=July 2015}} * An Apidya suite was performed live by a full symphonic orchestra in 2003 at the [[Symphonic Game Music Concert]]-series in Leipzig, Germany. * Music from Apidya was part of the 2006 PLAY! A [[Video Game Symphony]] concert in Stockholm, Sweden. * Music from Apidya (as well as many of Hülsbeck's other works) was played by a symphonic orchestra at the Symphonic Shades concert in 2008. ==Reception== The game was largely praised as a fine example of the shoot 'em up genre. [[Amiga Power]] magazine described the game as offering "more playability than any other shoot 'em up" and awarded the game 89% in 1992.{{cite journal |last1=Ramshaw |first1=Mark |title=none |journal=[[Amiga Power]] |volume= |issue=13 |pages=64–65 |publisher=Future Publishing |url=}} [[Amiga Format]] magazine awarded the game 90%.{{cite journal |last1=Leach |first1=James |title=none |journal=[[Amiga Format]] |volume= |issue=35 |pages=83 |publisher=Future Publishing |url=}} ==Legacy== An unofficial [[Game Boy Advance|GBA]] Apidya technical demo followed years later{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} and an unofficial Windows [[Video game remake|remake]] of the first level was released in 2002[http://apidya.vg-network.com/ Apidya 2002] but neither was ever completed. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1992 video games]] [[Category:Amiga games]] [[Category:Amiga-only games]] [[Category:Horizontally scrolling shooters]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games scored by Chris Huelsbeck]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Crossdressing}} '''Ball culture''', the '''house system''', the '''ballroom community''' and similar terms describe an underground [[LGBT]] [[subculture]] in the United States in which people "walk" (i.e., compete) for [[Trophy|trophies]] and prizes at events known as balls. Some who walk also dance; others compete in [[Drag (clothing)|drag]] categories, designed to emulate other genders and social classes. Most participants in ball culture belong to groups known as "houses".{{cite web|last=Podhurst |first=L. |author2=Credle J. |title=HIV/AIDS risk reduction strategies for Gay youth of color in the "house" community. (Meeting Abstracts) |publisher=[[U.S. National Library of Medicine]] |date=2007-06-10 |page=13 |volume=12 |issue=913 |location=Newark 07107-3000, US |url=http://gateway.nlm.nih.gov/MeetingAbstracts/102231503.html |accessdate=2007-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817103315/http://gateway.nlm.nih.gov/MeetingAbstracts/ma?f=102231503.html |archivedate=August 17, 2009 }}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/863223074|title=Voguing and the house ballroom scene of New York City 1989-92|last=Stuart.|first=Baker,|date=2011-01-01|publisher=s.n.|isbn=9780955481765|oclc=863223074}} ==Houses== Houses serve as alternative families, primarily consisting of Black and Latino [[gay]], [[Gender variance|gender nonconforming]] and [[transgender]] youth, and are meant to be [[safe space]]s.{{Cite news|url=http://www.standardhotels.com/culture/a-gif-guide-to-voguing--short-history|title=A GIF Guide to Voguing (+ Short History)|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en}} Houses are led by “mothers” and “fathers,” providing guidance and support for their house “children.”{{Cite journal|last=Bailey|first=Marlon|date=|title=Gender/Racial Realness: Theorizing the Gender System in Ballroom Culture|url=|journal=Feminist Studies|volume=37|pages=365–386}} Most houses operate in the same way. Houses exist across the United States and in over 15 cities, most being in the northeast. The major cities are [[New York City|New York]], [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Baltimore]], and [[Washington, D.C.]],{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Jonathon|date=|title=The Social World of Voguing|url=|journal=Journal for the Anthropological Study of Human Movement|volume=12|pages=26–42}} as well as [[Oakland]] and the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. Houses that win a lot of trophies and gain recognition, reach a rank of "legendary."{{Cite journal|last=Susman|first=Tara|date=|title=The Vogue of Life: Fashion Culture, Identity, and the Dance of Survival in the Gay BalIs|url=|journal=disClosure: A Journal of Social Theory|volume=9|pages=}} Notable houses include [[House of Ninja]] (founded by [[Willi Ninja]]), [[House of Aviance]] (founded by [[Mother Juan Aviance]]),Lewis, Darvin, ''How Big Is Your Faith: The Gospel of Down Low Fiction'', {{ISBN|9781434833471}}, (2008), p. 129, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YEjREFmJP7cC&pg=PA129&dq=%22house+of+aviance%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWr9fuwbLUAhWCJlAKHVDQBC8Q6AEIPDAF#v=onepage&q&f=false] [[House of Xtravaganza]] (founded by [[Hector Xtravaganza]], né Hector Valle), House of Princess, House of Infiniti, House of Mizrahi (founded by Jack and Andre Mizrahi), [[House of LaBeija]] (founded by [[Crystal LaBeija]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.rainbowhistory.org/html/drag.html|title=The Rainbow History Project: Drag in DC|date=2000–2007|publisher=Rainbow History Project|accessdate=2007-10-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140614052021/http://www.rainbowhistory.org/html/drag.html|archive-date=June 14, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}[http://www.combustiblecelluloid.com/archive/parisburn.shtml] ''Paris Is Burning'' (1991){{cite web|url=http://www.bentmagazine.com/issues/06-22/article022-MichaelCunningham.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070520135123/http://www.bentmagazine.com/issues/06-22/article022-MichaelCunningham.html |archivedate=May 20, 2007 }} ''Bent Magazine''[http://www.howdoilooknyc.org/] ''How Do I Look'', an instruction DVD with limited distribution in New York City and Philadelphia, delves into the houses of the New York City ball culture. [[House of Dupree]] (founded by [[Paris Dupree]]), House of Amazon (founded by [[Leiomy Maldonado|Leoimy Maldonado]]),{{Cite news|url=http://www.elle.com/fashion/news/a46227/nikes-newest-campaign-stars-vogue-legend-leiomy-maldonado/|title=Nike's New Ad Stars Vogue Legend Leiomy Maldonado|date=2017-06-26|work=ELLE|access-date=2017-10-13|language=en}} House of Mugler (founded by David, Raliegh and Julian),{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2014/nov/18/-sp-vogueing-dance-came-back-into-vogue-madonna|title=How voguing came back into vogue|last=Hunt|first=Kenya|date=2014-11-18|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-13|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} House Balenciaga (founded by Harold Balenciaga), House of Ebony (founded by Larry Ebony), and the House of Garcon{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/london-is-burning-how-queer-ballroom-culture-flourishes_us_5a2e660ce4b04e0bc8f3b682|title=London Is Burning! How Ballroom Culture Is Flourishing Abroad|last=Londyn|first=Andrew|date=2017-12-12|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-27}} (founded by Whitney and Shannon Garcon). Typically house members adopt the name of their house as their last name.{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2000-01-11/news/legends-of-the-ball/|title=Legends of the Ball: Paris Is Still Burning|last=Trebay|first=Guy|date=January 12–18, 2000|work=[[The Village Voice]]|author2=Credle J.|accessdate=2007-10-20}} Historically, four categories of gender exist within houses: Butch queens, femme queens, butches, and women. ==Competition== Houses "walk" (compete) against one another in "balls" judged on dance skills ([[Vogue (dance)|voguing]]), costumes, appearance, and [[Attitude (psychology)|attitude]]. Participants dress according to the category in which they are competing, and are expected to display appropriate "realness".{{cite web |last=Levy |first=Emanuel |title=Paris Is Burning (film review) |publisher=Emanuellevy.com |date=2004–2007 |url = http://emanuellevy.com/article.php?articleID=2151 |accessdate=2007-10-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070927184728/http://emanuellevy.com/article.php?articleID=2151| archivedate= September 27, 2007 | deadurl= no}} Balls are influenced by [[hip hop fashion]] and [[hip hop music|music]]. The largest balls last as long as ten hours, with dozens of categories in a single evening. With fewer spectators, nearly everyone comes to compete; some trophies are {{convert|12|ft}} tall, and a grand-prize winner can earn $1,000 or more. Although some competitive walks involve [[crossdressing]], in other cases the goal is to accentuate a male participant's [[masculinity]] or a female participant's [[femininity]] as a parody of heterosexuality. Voguing consists of five elements: duckwalk, catwalk, hands, floorwork, and spins & dips.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E3c7Gv5RHaw|title=The 5 Elements of Vogue with Leiomy Maldonado - In Progress {{!}} Oxygen|last=|first=|date=|website=Youtube|access-date=}} ==={{anchor|Some categories and their descriptions}}Categories=== Some categories include:{{Cite news|url=http://blackyouthproject.com/ballroom-scene-a-new-black-art/|title=The Ballroom Scene: A New Black Art - The Black Youth Project|date=2009-10-21|work=The Black Youth Project|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en-US}} *''Butch Queen Vogue Fem/Female Figure Performance'' – Use the [[Vogue (dance)|vogue]] elements of hands, catwalk, duckwalk, floor performance, spins and dips *''BQ Realness'' – Judged on participants' ability to blend in with male heterosexuals *''FQ Realness'' – Judged on participants' ability to [[Passing (gender)|blend in]] with [[cisgender]] women *''Realness With a Twist (Twister)'' – Judged on participants' ability to blend in with heterosexuals, then returning in vogue *''BQ/FQ/FF Runway'' – Judged on participants' ability to catwalk, usually with a requested outfit or color *''Bizarre'' – Judged on participants' creativity to design a costume based on a requested category *''Labels'' – Judged on how many labels a participant is wearing and their authenticity *''BQ/FQ/FF Face'' – Judging a participant's clean, smooth face *''BQ/FQ/FF Sex Siren'' – Sex appeal in underwear (thongs, briefs or bikinis) *''Commentator vs. Commentator'' – Allows aspiring (and current) MCs to showcase their ability to hype the crowd *''Dipology'' – Like Vogue Femme, with spins into dips only *''European Runway'' – Often a butch-queen category, featuring effects seen in a European fashion show *''American Runway'' – Similar to European Runway, featuring butch queens, trans men or Butches/Studs *''Butch Queen up in Pumps'' – Similar to Labels or Runway, featuring high heels *''FQ/BQ in Drag Female Figure Performance'' – Lip-synching to a female celebrity *''Hands Performance'' – Vogue with hands only *''Virgin/Beginners Vogue'' – Vogue category for participants who have been voguing for less than one year *''Virgin/Beginners Runway'' – Runway for participants who have been walking for less than one year *''Best Dressed'' *''Legendary/Iconic Categories'' – All-star categories for legends and Icons only *''Women's Vogue'' – Women Who Vogue All Around The World{{clarify|date=September 2014}} *''Face'': The face category is about who has a classically beautiful face. Judges examine the eyes, the nose, the teeth, the lips and the structure of the face. While the category may call for an effect, ultimately the judges will only look at the face of a competitor, which should not have much makeup and should appear flawless. *''Body'': This category is about health. The judges will be looking for someone who looks attractive, and healthy. Do not confuse this with sexiness, as there is a completely different category for that. *''Sex Siren'': Participants will do their best to tease, and titillate the judges. Some do so by stripping all their clothes off, others do it through erotic dancing, and some combine the two in order to attempt to win.{{Citation|last=BRTB TV (BALLROOM THROWBACKS)|title=BQ SEX SIREN @ VOGUE NIGHTS 5/11/2015|date=2015-05-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aI9XnM5VHis|accessdate=2017-05-02}} ==History== As a [[counterculture|countercultural]] phenomenon, ball culture is rooted in necessity and defiance. According to findings by Dr. Genny Beemyn addressed in their book ''Trans Bodies, Trans Selves'', members of the underground [[LGBT|LGBTQ+]] community in large cities of the late nineteenth century began to organize masquerade balls known as "drags" in direct defiance of laws banning citizens from wearing clothes of the opposite gender.{{Cite book|title=Trans Bodies, Trans Selves|last=Beemyn|first=Genny|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2014|isbn=0199325359|location=|pages=}} In his essay "Spectacles of Colors", [[Langston Hughes]] describes his experience at a drag ball in the 1920s.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SsgPcfpjhBcC&pg=PA208&dq=langston+hughes+spectacles+in+color&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjohcfVzfzZAhUD72MKHWLdCLEQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Collected Works of Langston Hughes|last=Hughes|first=Langston|date=2001|publisher=University of Missouri Press|isbn=9780826214102|language=en}}
"Strangest and gaudiest of all Harlem spectacles in the '20s, and still the strangest and gaudiest, is the annual Hamilton Club Lodge Ball at Rockland Palace Casino. I once attended as a guest of A'Lelia Walker. It is the ball where men dress as women and women dress as men. During the height of the New Negro era and the tourist invasion of Harlem, it was fashionable for the intelligentsia and social leaders of both Harlem and the downtown area to occupy boxes at this ball and look down from above at the queerly assorted throng on the dancing floor, males in flowing gowns and feathered headdresses and females in tuxedoes and box-back suits." —Langston Hughes
In the subsequent decades, drag balls eventually developed the modern, mainstream format we know today. The modern ballroom culture has existed for at least five decades. However, it remains largely underground and unknown for this particular community of Black and Latino queer youth. It began in Harlem more than 50 years ago, and has now expanded rapidly to other major cities such as [[Chicago]], Atlanta, Baltimore, Charlotte, Cleveland, Detroit, and Philadelphia. Moreover, with the advancements of social media, it has migrated to other countries such as [[Canada]], [[Japan]], and the [[United Kingdom|UK]].{{Cite journal|last=Bailey|first=Marlon M.|date=2014-04-21|title=Engendering space: Ballroom culture and the spatial practice of possibility in Detroit|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0966369X.2013.786688|journal=Gender, Place & Culture|volume=21|issue=4|pages=489–507|doi=10.1080/0966369X.2013.786688|issn=0966-369X}} Ball culture also known as "house ball culture," was first captured in Jennie Livingston's documentary, ''Paris is Burning'' (1990). ===New York City=== [[Cross dressing ball]]s had existed since the thirties, consisting of primarily white men, they competed in fashion shows in bars 2 or 3 times a year. Black queens would sometimes participate but rarely won any prizes. Due to discrimination, Black queens Crystal Labeija and her friend Lottie began their own drag ball titled 'House of Labeija,' kickstarting the ballroom scene in New York. In 1989, The House of Latex was created as a call to action in the ballroom community to bridge the gap between [[HIV]]-STI prevention and ballroom culture. === Washington, DC === {{more citations needed|date=June 2018}} This account from the metropolitan Washington, D.C. area describes how ball culture and drag houses developed about 1960:
Some regular house parties became institutionalized as drag "houses" and "families." The leader, or "mother," often provided not only the opportunity for parties but also instruction and mentoring in the arts of make-up, selecting clothes, lip-synching, portraying a personality, walking, and related skills. Those taught became "drag daughters," who in turn mentored others, creating entire "drag families." Drag houses became the first social support groups in the city's gay and lesbian community. House names often came from addresses of the house 'mother', such as Mother Billy Bonhill's Belmont House at 15th and Belmont NW, or associations with the "mother's" chosen personality, as Mame Dennis's Beekman Place.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
The dance styles which later characterized drag houses had not been developed; competitions between houses involved standard drag performances in which entertainers lip-synced or, rarely, sang. In contrast to the New York houses in Paris Is Burning, some of the Washington, D.C. house mothers were white. However, African-American drag queens were a prominent part of the community:
Venues for drag shows and competitions were a constant challenge in the 1960s. The Uptown Lounge sponsored monthly drag contests, an event later duplicated at Johnnie's on Capitol Hill. Chunga's drag shows at the Golden Key Club in North Beach, Maryland were a popular Sunday event. The major hotels' resistance to drag events was not broken until February 1968 when African-American drag impresario Black Pearl staged the gala Black Pearl International Awards at the Washington Hilton. It was the drag event of the year.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
The Washington, D.C. ball community consists primarily of African-American and Latino participants, and has adopted many attributes seen in Paris Is Burning. Nineteen-sixties-style drag shows and competitions still exist, with their own audience. Ball patrons will find similar categories (such as "banjee thug realness" and "vogue") as an audience member. The Washington ballroom scene was founded in 1986 by Icon Lowell Adonis-Khanh (Lowell Thomas Hickman) and Icon Eric Christian-Bazaar. During the 1990s, more houses appeared in the area due to the efforts of Twain Miyake-Mugler ("father" of the House of Miyake Mugler, D.C. Chapter), Icon Harold Balenciaga (founder of the house of Balenciaga), Icons Shannon Garcon and Whitney Garcon (founders of the House of Garcon{{Cite news|url=http://projects.aljazeera.com/2014/on-the-runway/|title=Ovahness Ball|work=Al Jazeera America|access-date=2018-06-27}} and charter members of The Legendary House of Miyake-Mugler).{{Cite web|url=http://walk4mewednesdays.com/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302220820/http://walk4mewednesdays.com/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-03-02|title=Walk For Me Online|date=2013-03-02|access-date=2018-06-27}} The city hosts a series of annual balls, in which contestants compete for trophies and cash prizes.{{anchor|Personality}} =={{anchor|Influence}}Influences== New York's legendary ballroom culture has had a huge culture impact from the 1980s until the present day.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jun/24/burning-down-the-house-debate-paris-is-burning|title=Burning down the house: why the debate over Paris is Burning rages on|last=Clark|first=Ashley|date=2015-06-24|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} ===Dance=== The most notable influence of ball culture on mainstream society is [[Vogue (dance)|voguing]], a dance style originating in Harlem ballrooms during the first half of the 20th century and popularized by the video for [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s "[[Vogue (Madonna song)|Vogue]]", released in 1990 (one year before the documentary ''[[Paris Is Burning (film)|Paris Is Burning]]'').{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GuJQSAiODqI|title=Madonna - Vogue (video)|last=|first=|date=|website=Youtube|access-date=}} The dance group Vogue Evolution, from ''[[America's Best Dance Crew]]'', has again sparked interest in voguing.[http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/arts/story.html?id=523c9eac-b15e-4824-ad95-9c92ff811018&k=61095] ''Ottawa Citizen'' September 6, 2006{{dead link|date=February 2015}} Vogueing was a powerful dance movement that originated in '70s and '80s New York among the predominantly black gay community in Harlem. Vogueing started in Drag Balls that were held by the queer community of color. The competitions were divided up into Houses that then competed in different categories, in which one of the categories was Voguing. It was during these dance offs that 'vogueing' was born. It was a non-violent battle of elegance and femininity named after a certain fashion magazine as it mirrored the poses held by models. It was all about arm and hand movements, with dancers often playing out elaborate scenes such as applying makeup or taking phone calls while dancing down the catwalk.{{Cite book|title=Staging desire : Queer readings of American theater history (Triangulations: lesbian/gay/queer theater/drama/performance).|last=Marra|first=K|location=Ann Arbor |publisher=University of Michigan Press|year=2002|isbn=|pages=}}{{Page needed|date=November 2018}} Willi Ninja was recognized as the "Grandfather of Vogue." Vogueing with its angular body movements, exaggerated model poses and intricate mime-like choreography and the colorful characters who populated Willi Ninja's world were introduced to the public at large by “Paris Is Burning,” the award-winning 1990 documentary about New York’s drag vogue-ball scene. Vogueing had been around for years, but Willi Ninja brought it to a level of visibility and perfection in performance that no one had ever reached.{{Page needed|date=November 2018}} ===Language=== Ball-culture terms are sometimes used more generally; "drag mother" may apply to any drag queen in a mentorship role, and "drag house" may refer to a group of drag performers allied personally or professionally. "Fierce" and "fierceness," "work it" and "working it," "fabulous" and "fabulousness" are heard in ''Paris Is Burning'' and appeared in the lyrics of "[[Supermodel (You Better Work)]]", a 1992 hit by [[drag queen]] [[RuPaul]]. These terms became more widely used in [[gay slang]], fashion industry [[jargon]] and mainstream [[colloquialism|colloquial]] language.''Fantabulosa: A Dictionary of Polari and Gay Slang'' by Paul Baker * Reading: to read a person is to highlight and exaggerate all of the flaws of a person, from their ridiculous clothes, to their flawed makeup and anything else the reader can come up with. It is a battle of wit, in which the winner is one who gets the crowd to laugh the most.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.com/article/art-of-shade-instagram-account|title=The Art of Shade Is the Instagram Account You Never Knew You Needed|work=Vogue|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en}} * [[Throw shade (slang)|Shade]]: shade is an art form that developed from Reading. Rather than the aim to insult, someone works with the medium of backhanded compliments. An example is to suggest that someone's beautiful dress makes people almost forget that she has a five o'clock shadow. * [[Yas (slang)|Yas]]: emphatic yes, the longer the "a" the greater the pleasure expressed * Voguing: dance invented in Harlem and performed notably by [[Willi Ninja]]{{Cite news|url=https://blog.oxforddictionaries.com/2018/01/09/linguistic-legacy-paris-is-burning/|title=The linguistic legacy of Paris is Burning - OxfordWords blog|date=2018-01-09|work=OxfordWords blog|access-date=2018-05-05|language=en-US}} * Walking: walking to acquire the admiration of ball contestants * Mopping: shoplifting clothes to wear for a ball * Working, or "work" for short : an exclamatory phrase used to connote admiration and content with someone's actions * Fierce: highest possible praise * Butch queen * Mother: hardest worker of a house, often taking a mentoring role for members of the house * House: alternative families * Chanté you stay: announcement of the winner of a lip-sync battle ===Music=== Ball culture has been fertile ground for new forms of [[house music]] and other genres of [[electronic dance music]] through its [[Disc jockey|DJs]].[https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00004RJEM ''Hang the DJ''] (2006) The culture has also influenced a wave of [[LGBT hip hop|queer hip hop]] artists such as [[Zebra Katz]], [[House of Ladosha]] and [[Le1f]] .[http://pitchfork.com/features/articles/8793-we-invented-swag/ "We Invented Swag: NYC's Queer Rap"]. [[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]], March 21, 2012.{{Citation|last=Mad Decent|title=Zebra Katz - Ima Read (ft. Njena Reddd Foxxx) [Official Full Stream]|date=2012-01-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oo4Sqt2Bmag|accessdate=2017-05-02}} ===Fashion=== Ball culture has influenced "the über-puffed-up peacock sexuality" of contemporary mainstream hip hop.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} A professor at [[New York University]] said about gay black culture, "Today's [[queer]] mania for [[ghetto fabulous]]ness and [[bling]] masks its elemental but silent relationship to even more queer impulses toward fabulousness in the 1980s."[http://www.e.bell.ca/filmfest/2005/films_description.asp?id=211 ''Pic Up the Mic''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202123550/http://www.e.bell.ca/filmfest/2005/films_description.asp?id=211 |date=February 2, 2007 }} at Toronto Film Festival.[http://www.emplive.org/education/index.asp?categoryID=26&ccID=127&xPopConfBioID=463&year=2005 "Don't Hate on Us, We're Fabulous: Notes on the History and Culture of Black Glam"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822085314/http://www.emplive.org/education/index.asp?categoryID=26&ccID=127&xPopConfBioID=463&year=2005 |date=August 22, 2006 }} ==={{anchor|Mainstream influence}}Mainstream entertainment=== In 2006, [[Beyoncé]] told a reporter from ''[[The Independent]]'' "how inspired she's been by the whole drag-house circuit in the States, an unsung part of black American culture where working-class gay men channel ultra-glamour in mocked-up catwalk shows. 'I still have that in me', she says of the 'confidence and the fire you see on stage...'"[http://news.independent.co.uk/people/profiles/article1223035.ece] ''The Independent'' Online, September 3, 2006 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001104054/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/profiles/article1223035.ece|date=October 1, 2007}}Emily A. Arnold & Marlon M. Bailey (2009) Constructing Home and Family: How the Ballroom Community Supports African American GLBTQ Youth in the Face of HIV/AIDS, Journal of Gay & Lesbian Social Services, 21: pp. 2–3, 171–188.Bailey, Marlon M. Feminist Studies, 37(2), pp. 365–386."The Ball Scene." House of Nuance. House of Nuance, 2012. Web. 4 November 2014.Battan, Carrie. "We Invented Swag: NYC's Queer Rap: How a group of NYC artists are breaking down ideas of hip-hop identity." Pitchfork Media. Pitchfork Media Ink, 2012. Web. 4 November 2014.Rowan D, Long D, Johnson D. Identity and Self-Presentation in the House/Ball Culture: A Primer for Social Workers. Journal of Gay & Lesbian Social Services [serial online]. April 2013; 25(2): pp. 178–196."In Baltimore, Ballroom Culture Is Transforming the Fight against HIV." Baltimoresun.com. N.p., n.d. Web. 4 November 2014.Bailey, M. M. (2014). Engendering space: Ballroom culture and the spatial practice of possibility in Detroit. Gender, Place & Culture: A Journal of Feminist Geography, 21(4), pp. 489–507. doi:10.1080/0966369X.2013.786688 ==In media== Most of the New York-based houses appeared in the 1991 documentary film ''[[Paris Is Burning (film)|Paris Is Burning]]''. The 2016 film ''[[Kiki (2016 film)|Kiki]]'' provided an updated portrait of the ball culture scene. In 2017, as part of a documentary series on New Zealand cultural identity, [[Vice Media]] produced an episode about New Zealand's ball culture, entitled "FAFSWAG: Auckland's Underground Vogue Scene".{{cite news |author= |title=Vice Doco Explores Auckland's Underground 'Vogueing' Scene |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=11851496 |work=New Zealand Herald |location=Auckland |date=May 8, 2017 |access-date=Sep 13, 2017 }} In 2018, [[Viceland]] aired a [[docuseries]], ''[[My House (2018 TV series)|My House]]'', following six people in the New York City ball culture.{{cite news|last1=Street|first1=Mikelle|title='My House' Highlights The Modern Ballroom Scene Post-'Paris Is Burning'|url=https://intomore.com/culture/My-House-Highlights-The-Modern-Ballroom-Scene-PostParis-Is-Burning/49242e7ca78b4bbb|accessdate=12 May 2018|work=INTO|date=25 April 2010}} In the spring of 2018, the television series ''[[Pose (TV series)|Pose]]'' premiered. Set in New York City 1987, it follows participants in Ball Culture, as well as others in 1980s New York. The show was created by Steven Canals, Brad Falchuk and Ryan Murphy.{{cite web|title=New Ryan Murphy Musical Dance Series POSE Gets Full Season Order|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/New-Ryan-Murphy-Musical-Dance-Series-POSE-Gets-Full-Season-Order-20171227|website=BroadwayWorld.com|accessdate=27 December 2017|language=en}} ==See also== {{Portal|LGBT |transgender|African American}} * [[Club Zanzibar]] * [[Drag ball]] * [[Drag show]] * [[Imperial Court System]] ;General * [[African-American culture and sexual orientation]] =={{anchor|Reference notes}}References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0100332|Paris is Burning}} – feature-length documentary * ''{{YouTube|DSFKZwyPwyI|Voguing: The Message}}'' (1989) – short documentary * Weems, M. (2008). A History of Festive Homosexuality: 1700–1969 CE. In The Fierce Tribe: Masculine Identity and Performance in the Circuit (pp. 81–100). (2nd Runner-up) | spouse = | domestic_partner = | children = | homepage = http://www.christopherbramell.com/ | signature = }} '''Christopher Bramell''' is an English [[Model (person)|model]], actor and the winner of Mr England 2015 / 2016.{{cite web|title=Aldi worker scoops Mr England title|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3205870/Chiselled-Aldi-worker-scoops-Mr-England-title-working-budget-supermarket.html|website=DailyMail.co.uk}}{{cite web|title=Christopher Bramell crowned Mr England|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/real-life-stories/supermarket-hunk-crowned-mr-england-6293774|website=Mirror.co.uk}} He represented England at [[Mister World 2016]] and came 4th place out of 46 entrants. ==Early life and career== Bramell was born in [[Liverpool]] on 24 May 1993. He graduated from [[Edge Hill University]] with a BA Honours Sports Development and Science degree. He worked at a local [[Aldi]] supermarket while launching his modelling and acting career. His modelling career was launched when he was spotted by the Mr Liverpool pageant organiser while working as a checkout assistant. He then went on to win the Mr England 2015/ 2016 competition{{cite web|title=Christopher Bramell wins Mr England|url=http://www.pukaarnews.com/store-assistant-christopher-bramell-wins-mr-england-2015/15021/|website=PukaarNews.com}} against already established models. Bramell also works as an actor and continued to work his full-time job at the local supermarket{{cite web|title=Aldi shop worker hoping to become the worlds most desirable man|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/meet-aldi-shop-worker-netherley-11523100|website=LiverpoolEcho.co.uk}} while competing. He represented England at the Mister World 2016 pageant held in [[Southport]],{{cite web|title=Meet the contestants|url=http://www.southportvisiter.co.uk/news/southport-news/meet-mr-world-competitors-way-11588134|website=SouthportVisiter.co.uk}} England on 19 July 2016{{cite web|title=Mr. World is back!|url=http://www.mrworld.tv/shownews/Mr-World-is-back!/273.html#.V5eV6JOANBd|website=Mr World}} and was among the Top 5 finalists coming in at 4th place. Bramell was the overall winner of the sports challenge giving him fast track to the top 5 of the competition. Bramell also won sub-awards while at Mister World including the Golf Challenge, 1st runner up in the [[Southport Pier]] Challenge{{cite web|title=46 contestant but only one winner|url=http://www.mrworld.tv/pages/The-Competition/17.html#.V5eXdZOANBd|website=MrWorld.tv}} and member of the winning team for the extreme sports group rounds. Bramell placed 4th in the competition above any other contestant competing from the United Kingdom or Europe. During his time as Mr England Bramell has done a lot of work for charity. One of his greatest achievements was organising a charity catwalk featuring amputees, children with cancer and women with breast cancer in order to help them build back up their self-esteem. Bramell has also done a lot of work in his local community including working with the Merseyside Society for Deaf People and delivering over 100 Easter eggs to homeless shelters in Liverpool and to the children’s ward at [[Whiston Hospital]]. Bramell continues to support charities close to his heart as well as being an Ambassador for Beauty with a Purpose, a global humanitarian charity which helps underprivileged children around the globe. Bramell's TV work includes appearing in Channel 4's [[Hollyoaks]], ITV's [[Emmerdale]] and [[Britain's Got Talent|Britain's Got More Talent]]. Bramell was chosen to represent England in Manhunt International 2016 and placed 3rd out of 50 other contestants. On 21 May 2017, Bramell represented England at the [[Mister Global|Mister Global 2017]] held in [[Chiang Mai, Thailand]] and was awarded the title of 2nd Runner-up. ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bramell, Christopher}} [[Category:1993 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of Edge Hill University]] [[Category:Beauty pageant contestants]] [[Category:English male models]] [[Category:English male television actors]] [[Category:Male beauty pageant winners]] [[Category:People from Liverpool]]

{{For|the Deep Forest album|Comparsa (album)}} {{refimprove|date=May 2015}} [[File:Chica en Comparsa, Carnavales de Maturin.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Comparsa on the streets of [[Maturín]], [[Venezuela]].]] A '''comparsa''' is a group of singers, musicians and dancers that take part in [[carnivals]] and other festivities in [[Spain]] and [[Latin America]]. Its precise meaning depends on the specific regional celebration. The most famous comparsas are those that participate in the [[Carnival of Santiago de Cuba]]. In Brazil, comparsas are called [[carnival block]]s, as those seen in the [[Rio Carnival|Carnival of Rio de Janeiro]] and other [[Brazilian carnival]]s. In the US, especially at the [[New Orleans Mardi Gras]], comparsas are called [[krewe]]s, which include [[Float (parade)|floats]].
== Spain == [[File:Carnaval de Malaga 1925 comparsa Pescadores Calabreses Bonitos Tangos.jpg|thumb|right|200px|1925 book of songs by the Pescadores Calabreses comparsa from the Carnival of [[Málaga]], [[Spain]].]] In Spain, the term comparsa can have different meanings depending on the celebration.
=== Cádiz === In [[Cádiz]] and other parts of [[Andalusia]], comparsas are groups of singers that take part in carnivals, especially the [[Carnival of Cádiz]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mintz|first1=Jerome R.|title=Carnival song and society: gossip, sexuality, and creativity in Andalusia|date=1997|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford, UK|isbn=185973183X|page=xxx}}</ref> They sing comedy routines and the best comparsa is chosen in a contest. Other ensembles can also be found at the carnival, such as [[chirigota]]s, coros de carnaval, and cuartetos carnavalescos.
=== Santa Cruz de Tenerife === In the [[Carnival of Santa Cruz de Tenerife]], comparsas are similar to Brazilian carnival blocks.<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5RUKAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA302 | page = 302 | title = Continuum encyclopedia of popular music of the world, Volumes 3-7 | editor = John Shepherd | publisher = Continuum | year = 2005 | isbn = 0826474365 }}</ref>
==Caribbean== === Cuba === {{see also|Conga (music)}} Cuban comparsas originate in the eastern part of the island, specifically in the streets of [[Santiago de Cuba]]. Comparsas are groups of singers, musicians and dancers. The singers and musicians form part of the [[conga (music)|conga]], the ensemble that specifically plays the carnival music (a genre also called conga). The rest of the comparsa is formed by dancers with defined costumes and choreographies. Apart from the large [[Carnival of Santiago de Cuba]], there is a carnival in Havana with slightly different customs. Famous comparsas from Santiago include Los Hoyos, Paso Franco, Guayabito, San Agustín, San Pedrito and Alto Pino.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Henken|first1=Ted A.|last2=Celaya|first2=Miriam|last3=Castellanos|first3=Dima|title=Cuba|date=2013|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, CA|page=408|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Pe_XAQAAQBAJ}}</ref> Famous comparsas from Havana include La Sultana, El Alacrán and [[Guaracheros de Regla]].
=== Dominican Republic === [[File:Diablo Cojuelo, diablo Mambero.jpg|thumb|180x180px|Diablo Cojuelo tradicional del carnaval Dominicano]] Dominican Republic comparsas or troupes are dance groups choosing a traditionally festive or allegorical subject to typical Dominican things, organizing a presentation with costumes and mask. Diablo Cojuelo is the most popular character in the Dominican carnival and each province has unique elements.
=== Belize === Throughout the country, particularly in [[Corozal Town]] and [[San Pedro Town]], comparsas are groups of street dancers which perform carnival season. The dancers dress up in traditional Mayan clothes.
==South America== === Argentina === In Argentina, comparsas are very similar to the Brazilian [[carnival block]]s, being followed by carriages.
=== Uruguay === In Uruguay, a comparsa makes reference to a group of [[candombe]] dancers and drummers.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox film festival | name = Deauville American Film Festival | image = | image_size = | caption = | number = | founded = 1975 | location = [[Deauville]], France | language = English, French | website = {{url|festival-deauville.com}} }}
[[File:SharonStone32.JPG|thumb|[[Sharon Stone]] at the Deauville American Film Festival in 1991]]
The '''Deauville American Film Festival''' ({{lang-fr|'''Festival du cinéma américain de Deauville'''}}) is a yearly [[film festival]] devoted to [[Cinema of the United States|American cinema]], taking place since 1975 in [[Deauville]], France.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/26/world/europe/26iht-srgaDEAUVILLE26.html|publisher=The New York Times|title=A French Town's Bright Shine Belies Its Size|author=Christopher F. Schuetze|date=25 May 2011|accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2010/08/08/travel/08Cover.html?pagewanted=all|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=9 March 2012|title=Normandy’s Quiet Glamour|date=5 August 2010|author=Seth Sherwood}}</ref>
It was established by Lionel Chouchan, André Halimi, and then Mayor of [[Deauville]] [[Michel d'Ornano]], with support from the [[Groupe Lucien Barrière]] in providing a luxurious setting for the Festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deauville American Film Festival history|url=http://www.festival-deauville.com/DEV/index.php?pid=49|website=www.festival-deauville.com|accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref> Although not competitive at its origin, the festival began to award prizes in 1995, for [[feature film]]s, and 1998 for [[short film]]s.
==Awards==
===Grand Prix=== This award was named ''Grand Prix spécial Deauville'' from 1995 to 2007 and ''Grand Prix du cinéma indépendant américain'' in 1998 and 1999.
*1995 : ''[[Living in Oblivion]],'' directed by [[Tom DiCillo]] *1996 : ''[[The Daytrippers]],'' directed by [[Greg Mottola]] *1997 : ''[[Sunday (1997 film)|Sunday]],'' directed by [[Jonathan Nossiter]] *1998 : ''[[Next Stop Wonderland]],'' directed by [[Brad Anderson (director)|Brad Anderson]] *1999 : ''[[Being John Malkovich]],'' directed by [[Spike Jonze]] *2000 : ''[[Girlfight]],'' directed by [[Karyn Kusama]] *2001 : ''[[Hedwig and the Angry Inch (film)|Hedwig and the Angry Inch]],'' directed by [[John Cameron Mitchell]] *2002 : ''[[Raising Victor Vargas]],'' directed by [[Peter Sollett]] *2003 : ''[[What Alice Found]],'' directed by [[A. Dean Bell]] *2004 : ''[[Maria Full of Grace]],'' directed by [[Joshua Marston]] *2005 : ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]],'' directed by [[Paul Haggis]] *2006 : ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]],'' directed by [[Jonathan Dayton]] et [[Valerie Faris]] *2007 : ''[[The Dead Girl]],'' directed by [[Karen Moncrieff]] *2008 : ''[[The Visitor (2007 drama film)|The Visitor]],'' directed by [[Tom McCarthy (director)|Tom McCarthy]] *2009 : ''[[The Messenger (2009 film)|The Messenger]],'' directed by [[Oren Moverman]] *2010 : ''[[Mother and Child (film)|Mother and Child]],'' directed by [[Rodrigo García (director)|Rodrigo García]] *2011 : ''[[Take Shelter]]'', directed by [[Jeff Nichols]] *2012 : ''[[Beasts of the Southern Wild]]'', directed by [[Benh Zeitlin]] *2013 : ''[[Night Moves (2013 film)|Night Moves]]'', directed by [[Kelly Reichardt]] *2014 : ''[[Whiplash (2014 film)|Whiplash]]'', directed by [[Damien Chazelle]] *2015 : ''[[99 Homes]]'', directed by [[Ramin Bahrani]] *2016 : ''[[Little Men (2016 film)|Little Men]]'', directed by [[Ira Sachs]] *2017: ''[[The Rider (film)|The Rider]],'' directed by [[Chloé Zhao]] *2018: ''[[Thunder Road (2018 film)|Thunder Road]],'' directed by Jim Cummings
===Prix du Jury=== The award was called ''Prix du jury spécial Deauville'' (Special Deauville Jury Award) from 1995 through 1997 and ''Prix spécial du jury du cinéma indépendant américain'' (Special Jury Award of American Independent Film) in 1998 and 1999.

=== Prix d'Ornano-Valenti === The Prix d'Ornano-Valenti (previously "Prix Michel d'Ornano") is awarded annually to a debut French film. It carries a grant of 3,000 euros for the awarded director-writer, 3,000 euros for the film's producer, and 10,000 euros for the French distributor to help promote the film. The award, which is named in honour of the former Mayor of [[Deauville]] and co-founder of the festival, [[Michel d'Ornano]], is supported by the Franco-American Cultural Fund.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wm-services.sacem.fr/cms/site/en/home/about-sacem/the-michel-d-orano-award|title=Deauville : The Michel d'Ornano Award |work=SACEM}}</ref>

revision.text:
Rigging in entertainment can be broken down into two main subjects – [[theatrical rigging]] and [[arena rigging]]. All the same skills apply in both genres. The first takes place in a [[theatre (structure)|theatre]], and typically involves the theatre's permanent [[fly system]]. The other in an [[arena]] or "exposed structure venue" such as a [[convention center]], [[ballroom]], [[warehouse]] etc. Many arena riggers find themselves hanging a full [[proscenium]] theater in an arena environment.<ref>'''Entertainment Rigging''' [http://www.beyondrigging.com/2014/04/stage-rigging-books-recommendation/ "'''Great Stage Rigging Books Sharing'''"]</ref>
Circus rigging, comprising aerial acrobatic apparatuses that support human beings under dynamic loading conditions, and stabilization rigging for large scale fabric tension structures (big tops), is, perhaps, under appreciated in the general rigging field, and may be considered by some to be a separate field. However, the principles of physics and the standards of engineering that apply to theatrical and arena rigging still hold true in circus rigging, and much of the same equipment and many of the same devices are commonly used. All the same skills apply in this genre as well.
Chain motors and trusses are not used as often in tented circuses as in arena or theater rigging, however arena circuses make regular use of them. In both tented and arena circuses, crane-bars or frames stabilized by guy cables, hung from fiber rope block and tackle systems are common, as are systems supporting and tensioning safety nets.
High (or low) wire rigging, while simple in principle and application, requires substantial load-path capacity, as wire walkers generally require high tension in their systems.
Automation rigging is used by many circuses, to fly both human beings and scenic or prop elements.
In theatrical rigging the venue may have anything from a dead pull scenery flying system, a [[Theatrical rigging#Hemp rigging system|hemp rigging system]], a [[Theatrical rigging#Counterweight rigging system|counterweight rigging system]], a [[winch]] or [[hoist (device)|hoist]] driven [[Theatrical rigging#Automated rigging system|automated rigging system]], or any hybrid of the aforementioned, used to fly props, people and scenery.
==Stations== Both of these rigging disciplines have four basic stations.
===Ground rigger=== Maintains safe perimeters underneath high work being done, maintains a safe path and perimeter around aerial work platforms, monitors the movement of aerial work platforms, assembles rigging on the ground for high work being done, attaches gear and assemblies to lines for high work being done, marks or "lays " out points on the floor and moves designators for high work (rigging points and laser plumbs), assembles and checks out [[Motion control|motion control systems]], makes attachments to lifting frames, lighting trusses, audio, video and scenery for hoisting or flying, does visual and mechanical safety inspections.
===Bucket rigger=== Has all of the skills and responsibility of a ground rigger and must also be able to operate an [[aerial work platform]], must be able to identify suitable structure and attachment for rigging, must be able to lift 100 lbs, must have advanced rope skills, be able to apply rope work mechanical advantages, as well as knowledge of materials, manufacturing methods and the proper applications of different rigging systems..
===High rigger/ Up rigger=== Is virtually identical to a bucket rigger, only they apply their trade while standing, sitting on or hanging from an exposed structural member.
===Climbing or rope access rigger=== Has all of the previous skills and responsibilities of the other 3 riggers and they must also have exceptional rope skills. They must also be very physically fit and able to pull their own body weight up into structural ceilings on belay while applying personal fall protection as they go. They must be proficient with harness positioning systems and advanced rope friction and hauling systems.
==Training== Most entertainment rigging training is done either by [[apprenticeship]] or formal training through unions i.e. [[IATSE]].<ref>http://www.iatselocal720.com/</ref> The recognized entertainment rigging certification is the E.T.C.P. arena and theater rigging certification programs.<ref>http://etcp.esta.org/</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== {{cite book|title=Entertainment Rigging|first=Harry|last=Donovan|year=1999|publisher=SAP|isbn=}}
{{Stagecraft}} [[Category:Entertainment occupations]]

revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox comics genre <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> |title = Fantasy comics |image=Forbidden Worlds 1.jpg |caption=''Forbidden Worlds'' a common example of 1950s fantasy anthologies |alt = |genre = [[Fantasy]] |pub# = <!-- up to 5 --> |title1 = [[Elfquest]] |title2 = [[Tarzan (comics)|Tarzan]] |title3 = [[House of Mystery]] |person1 = [[Steve Ditko]] |person2 = [[Frank Frazetta]] |person3 = [[Wally Wood]] |person4 = [[Gaylord Dubois]] |series# = <!-- up to 5 --> |base# = <!-- up to 5 --> |subs1 = [[:Category:Wuxia comics|Wuxia comics]] |subs2 = [[:Category:Comics based on fairy tales|Fairy tale comics]] |subs3 = [[:Category:Science fantasy comics|Science fantasy comics]] |related1 = [[Horror comics]] |cat = Fantasy comics |cattop = |}} {{Fantasy}} '''[[Fantasy]] [[comics]]''' have been around as long as the medium itself.
==History== {{Original research|section|date=August 2016}}In the US market, early years of fantasy comics began in the [[Golden Age of Comic Books]] and were populated with such notable works range from All-American comics' (and later DC comics') Greek myth inspired super hero [[Wonder Woman]] to [[Dell]]'s [[Tarzan (comics)|Tarzan]].
Starting in the late 1940s through the mid-1950s horror-themed fantasy anthologies gained prominence; the most famous of these include [[EC Comics]]' ''[[Tales from the Crypt (comics)|Tales from the Crypt]]'','' [[Haunt of Fear]]'', and ''[[Vault of Horror]]''; and lesser notable titles such as [[American Comics Group]] ''[[Adventures into the Unknown]]'' and'' [[Forbidden Worlds]]'' though this trend saw its prevalence cease with the publication of [[Fredric Wertham|Dr. Fredric Wertham]]'s book ''[[Seduction of the Innocent]]'' which directly led to a Senate hearing of the influence of comics on juvenile violence. Though fantasy comics were able to survive in this new atmosphere though in a diminished capacity compared to its much stronger output in these early years.
Fantasy-themed super heroes continued to populate comics through the 1950s and regained popularity in the 1960s with such characters as [[Steve Ditko]]'s [[Doctor Strange]] published by [[Marvel comics]] and [[Jack Kirby]]'s [[Thor (Marvel Comics)|Thor]] both appearing in two of Marvel's fantasy-themed anthologies – [[Strange Tales]] and [[Journey into Mystery]].
In the 1970s, [[Conan the Barbarian]], created by [[Robert E. Howard]], became one of the most popular publications of [[Marvel Comics]]. After some changes of publishers, it continued to be published in the 2010s.
In the 1990s, [[The Sandman (Vertigo)|The Sandman]], created by [[Neil Gaiman]], [[Sam Kieth]] and [[Mike Dringenberg]] was popular.
==Notable creators== * [[Al Feldstein]] * [[Frank Frazetta]] * [[Otto Binder]] * [[Gardner Fox]] * [[Steve Ditko]] * [[Jack Kirby]] * [[Jean Giraud|Moebius]] * [[Joe Orlando]] * [[Osamu Tezuka]] * [[Bernie Wrightson]] * [[Hal Foster]] * [[Jim Starlin]] * [[Al Williamson]] * [[Wallace Wood]]
==Adaptations== Several fantasy [[manga]] have been or will be adapted into [[anime]] television series, including ''[[Hakkenden: Eight Dogs of the East]]'' (2013),<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-10-27/hakkenden/toho-hakken-ibun-fantasy-manga-gets-anime|title= Hakkenden: Tōhō Hakken Ibun Fantasy Manga Gets Anime|date= 27 October 2011|accessdate= 30 July 2014|work= [[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> ''[[Akame ga Kill!]]'' (2014),<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-01-20/akame-ga-kill-dark-action-fantasy-manga-gets-tv-anime|title= Akame ga KILL! Dark Action Fantasy Manga Gets TV Anime|date= 20 January 2014|accessdate= 30 July 2014|work= [[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> ''[[The Seven Deadly Sins (manga)|The Seven Deadly Sins]]'' (2014),<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-04-11/the-seven-deadly-sins-fantasy-manga-gets-tv-anime|title= The Seven Deadly Sins Fantasy Manga Gets TV Anime|date= 11 April 2014|accessdate= 30 July 2014|work= [[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> ''[[Trinity Seven]]'' (2014)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-02-13/school-fantasy-manga-trinity-seven-has-anime-in-the-works|title= School Fantasy Manga Trinity Seven Has Anime in the Works|date= 13 February 2014|accessdate= 30 July 2014|work= [[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> and ''[[Akatsuki no Yona]]'' (TBA).<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-07-01/akatsuki-no-yona-shojo-fantasy-manga-gets-tv-anime/.76174|title= Akatsuki no Yona Shōjo Fantasy Manga Gets TV Anime|date= 1 July 2014|accessdate= 30 July 2014|work= [[Anime News Network]]}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of fantasy comics]]

{{Infobox organization/Wikidata | fetchwikidata = ALL | name = French Federation of Conjurers | native_name = Fédération Française des Artistes Prestidigitateurs }} The '''French Federation of Conjurers (FFAP)''' (Fédération Française des Artistes Prestidigitateurs<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.lessor42.fr/serge-odin-la-magie-dans-les-g-nes-5277.html|title=Serge Odin, la magie dans les gènes|last=lessor42.fr|work=L'Essor Loire|access-date=2018-06-03|language=fr-FR}}</ref>) is a regional member organisation of [[Fédération Internationale des Sociétés Magiques|FISM]]. As of 2013, Serge Odin is the president of the organisation.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forez-info.com/actualite/divers/21322-serge-odin-president-des-magiciens.html|title=Forez Info - Serge Odin, président des magiciens|last=FI|website=www.forez-info.com|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Lew Bloom | image = Harvard Theatre Collection - Lew Bloom TCS 1.2687 - cropped.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Bloom as his "tramp" character | birth_name = Ludwig Pflum | birth_date = {{birth date|1859|08|08|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania, U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1929|12|12|1859|08|08|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Manhattan, New York City]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Charles Evans Cemetery]] | nationality = American | other_names = Bud Bloom | education = Poplar Street School | occupation = Vaudeville performer, art collector, art dealer, painter | spouse = {{marriage|Jane Cooper|1892|December 12, 1929|end=his death}} }}
'''Lew Bloom''' (August 8, 1859 – December 12, 1929) was an American [[vaudeville]] performer and stage actor who popularized the comical [[tramp]] character. After retiring from the stage in the 1910s, he became a prolific [[art collector]] and [[Art dealer|dealer]] and also painted his own original works.
Decades after his death, art conservators discovered that Bloom was the perpetrator of an [[art forgery]] involving an oil portrait that he claimed depicted the wife of President [[Abraham Lincoln]], [[First Lady]] [[Mary Todd Lincoln]].
==Early life== Bloom was born '''Ludwig Pflum''' in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] to Ludwig and Louisa (''née'' Moyer) Pflum. His parents, who immigrated from Germany, had six other children: Susannah, Susan Deborah, Louisa, Charles, Edward and Adolph (who died as a child). Bloom's father worked as a [[Cooper (profession)|cooper]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Montgomery|first=Morton Luther |title=Historical and Biographical Annals of Berks County, Pennsylvania, Embracing a Concise History of the County and a Genealogical Record of Representative Families|year=1909|publisher=J.H. Beers & Company|page=874}}</ref> The family eventually moved to [[Reading, Pennsylvania]] where Bloom attended Poplar Street School. Around 1871, the family moved to [[Williamsburg, Pennsylvania|Williamsburg]] where Bloom began working as a [[jockey]]. In 1873, he joined the Potter Hart Colossus Circus where he performed a "bounding jockey act" in which he rode horses and performed [[acrobatics]]. During his time at the circus, "Ludwig Pflum" changed his name to "Lew Bloom" and would use that name for the remainder of his performing career.<ref name="readingobit">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19291213&id=blExAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5uEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1702,2814709|title=Death Claims Originator Of Tramp Act|date=December 13, 1929|work=Reading Eagle|page=2|accessdate=March 1, 2015|location=Reading, Pennsylvania}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early years=== Bloom spent several years touring in variety shows with his jockey act before relocating to [[Dover, Delaware]] where he competed in horse [[Match racing|match races]]. He then returned to Reading where he and a friend opened the Drovers' Hotel. The establishment was the first to introduce [[cabaret]] to Reading. Bloom performed song and dance acts at the hotel and also began competing as a [[Lightweight#Professional boxing|lightweight boxer]].<ref name="readingobit"/>
Bloom later became the [[stage manager]] for his friend's second establishment, The General Taylor Hotel. He left after two years to work as a [[clown]] in the Shelby, Pullman & Hamilton Circus. After a year, Bloom returned to Reading where formed a partnership with vaudevillian Howard Monroe. The duo performed song and dance numbers and comedy skits in [[blackface]] until Bloom left the duo and went to New York to perform comedy as a solo act.<ref name="readingobit"/>
===Stage and vaudeville=== In 1885, Bloom was cast in the play ''Nobody's Claim'', followed by a role in ''The Red Spider'' in 1888. It was his role in the latter production where he first conceived of the [[tramp]] persona.<ref name="readingobit"/><ref name=DePastino157>{{cite book|last=DePastino|first=Todd|title=Citizen Hobo: How a Century of Homelessness Shaped America|year=2003|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=0-226-14378-3|page=157}}</ref>
Bloom's "Society Tramp" character was a philosophical, shabbily dressed homeless man who drank frequently and was generally treated poorly by other characters. Despite his lowly status, the tramp would make light of his predicament and maintained a positive and comicial outlook.<ref>{{cite book|last=Curtis|first=James|title=W.C. Fields: A Biography|year=2003|publisher=A.A. Knopf|isbn=0-375-40217-9|page=46}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Louvish|first=Simon|authorlink=Simon Louvish|title=Chaplin: The Tramp's Odyssey|year=2009|publisher=Faber & Faber|isbn=0-571-23768-1|page=49}}</ref><ref name="kusmer">{{cite book|last=Kusmer|first=Kenneth L. |title=Down and Out, on the Road: The Homeless in American History|year=2002|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-195-04778-8|page=186}}</ref> Typically, tramp characters like Bloom's included slapstick comedy routines as well as dancing or [[pantomime]].<ref name="kusmer"/> One of Bloom's tramp character's jokes was, "I don't spend all my time in saloons. I can't. They have to close up some time."<ref name=Slide56>{{cite book|last=Slide|first=Anthony|authorlink=Anthony Slide|title=The Encyclopedia of Vaudeville|year=2012|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|isbn=978-1-61703-249-3|page=56}}</ref>
Bloom's tramp character became a big hit with audiences and was quickly copied by hundreds of other performers of the era including [[Nat M. Wills]] and Charles R. Sweet.<ref name="readingobit"/><ref name=DePastino157/> [[Charlie Chaplin]] and [[W. C. Fields]] also established long and successful stage and film careers portraying their version of the tramp persona.<ref name=Glyn200>{{cite book|last=Vincent|first=Glyn Vincent|title=he Unknown Night: The Genius and Madness of R. A. Blakelock, an American Painter|year=2003|publisher=Grove Press|isbn=0-802-14064-5|page=200}}</ref> Bloom would later insist he originated the character and that he was "the first stage tramp in the business".<ref name=DePastino157/>
Bloom's stage career peaked in the 1890s.<ref name=Slide56/> Throughout the decade, he continued to portray tramps in various stage productions by [[Charles Hale Hoyt]] including ''A Black Sheep'', ''On the Bowery'', ''A Milk White Flag'', ''A Day and a Night'' and ''A Society Tramp''. After leaving Hoyt in 1892, Bloom and his wife (whom he married in 1892), known as "Miss Jane Cooper", toured the vaudeville circuit with their comedy act "A Picture of Life". Bloom played his usual tramp role while his wife played the comic foil - a "New England spinster" or a "city maiden."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=18990115&id=y8AhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LZ0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6058,2644891|title=Bud Bloom, Reading, The Original Tramp|date=January 15, 1899|work=Reading Eagle|page=9|accessdate=March 1, 2015|location=Reading, Pennsylvania}}</ref>
By 1909, Bloom's tramp persona had run its course and his career began to wane. At least one critic during that time said that Bloom had become "the worst act on the bill" of vaudeville shows.<ref>{{cite news|title=Orpheum review|date=August 28, 1909|work=Goodwin's Weekly|page=8|location=Salt Lake City, Utah}}</ref>
==Later years== After retiring from performing in the late 1910s, Bloom lived in [[Mount Penn, Pennsylvania]] where he spent his time painting in his studio and collecting and dealing art.<ref name="readingobit"/><ref name="reading4">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19070406&id=DowtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lJsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2175,549832&hl=en|title=Paintings Of Lew Bloom Exhibited|date=April 6, 1907|work=Reading Eagle|page=4|accessdate=September 2, 2015|location=Reading, Pennsylvania}}</ref> He began purchasing artwork during his stage career.<ref name="readingobit"/> Between 1889 and 1892, he purchased thirty to forty paintings from artist [[Ralph Albert Blakelock]].<ref name=Glyn200/> Upon his sister Susan's death in 1910, he inherited her art collection.<ref name="brudereck">{{cite web|url=http://www2.readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=365893|title=Berks man bilked Honest Abe's kin?|last=Brudereck|first=Jason|date=February 18, 2012|publisher=readingeagle.com}}</ref> In April 1907, Bloom exhibited seven pieces of his original works at the Reinhard Rieger Gallery in Mount Penn. The exhibition also included a copy of ''The Brooklet In the Meadow'', by Herman Rheudesela that Bloom painted (the original painting was also exhibited).<ref name="reading4"/> Bloom later moved to New York and occasionally returned to his hometown of Reading to spend time with his family and attend [[Elks Club]] meetings. He also trained horses for Metropolitan Race Clubs in the New York and Pennsylvania area and in [[Cuba]].<ref name="readingobit"/>
==Death== On December 10, 1929, Bloom was admitted to [[Bellevue Hospital]] in [[Manhattan, New York City]]. He died there two days later of "complication of diseases" at the age of 70.<ref name="readingobit"/> Bloom's funeral was held at the Seidel Funeral Chapel in Reading on December 16. He was buried at [[Charles Evans Cemetery]] the following morning.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19291215&id=cFExAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5uEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2544,3326317|title=Lew Bloom To Be Buried Here|date=December 15, 1929|work=Reading Eagle|page=2|accessdate=March 1, 2015|location=Reading, Pennsylvania}}</ref>
==Mary Todd Lincoln hoax== In early 1929, Bloom made news when he announced that he had acquired a previously unknown oil portrait of former [[First Lady]] [[Mary Todd Lincoln]], the widow of slain president [[Abraham Lincoln]]. Bloom claimed shortly before President Lincoln was [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln|assassinated on April 14, 1865]], Mary Lincoln commissioned painter [[Francis Bicknell Carpenter]] (who had lived at the [[White House]] for six months during Lincoln's presidency and had previously painted ''[[First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation of President Lincoln]]'') to paint a portrait of her as gift to her husband. After the President's death, Bloom claimed that Mary Lincoln was unable to pay Carpenter for the painting and asked him to destroy it. According to Bloom, Carpenter kept the painting and eventually sold it to a wealthy Philadelphia shipbuilder named Jacob G. Neafie who was a great fan of President Lincoln's.<ref name="cohen">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/12/arts/design/portrait-of-mary-todd-lincoln-is-deemed-a-hoax.html|title=Mrs. Lincoln, I Presume? Well, as It Turns Out ...|last=Cohen|first=Patricia|date=February 11, 2012|publisher=nytimes.com}}</ref><ref name="wetterich2">{{cite web|url=http://www.galesburg.com/article/20120214/News/302149994/?Start=2|title=Fake Mary Todd painting makes it even more famous|last=Wetterich|first=Chris|date=February 14, 2012|publisher=galesburg.com|page=2|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> After Neafie died, Bloom said that Neafie's daughter inherited the portrait who then gave it to Bloom's sister Susan as gift for taking care of her mother, Anna "Annie" Neafie, who died in 1860.<ref name="cohen"/><ref name="hageman">{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-04-16/entertainment/ct-ent-0417-lincoln-restoration-20120416_1_barry-bauman-conservator-case-study|title=Anatomy of a fake Lincoln|last=Hageman|first=William|date=April 16, 2012|publisher=chicagotribune.com}}</ref> Upon Susan's death in 1910, Bloom inherited her art collection which he said included the portrait of Mary Lincoln.<ref name="brudereck"/>
To validate his claim of the portrait's authenticity, Bloom attached a notarized [[affidavit]] to it and displayed the portrait at Milch Galleries in Manhattan. Shortly before his death in December 1929, he sold the portrait to President and Mary Lincoln's granddaughter [[Jessie Harlan Lincoln]], the daughter of the Lincolns' eldest and only surviving son [[Robert Todd Lincoln]].<ref name="wetterich2"/> The exact sale price is unknown, but is believed to be between $2,000 to $3,000 (approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|2000|1929|r=-3}}}} to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|3000|1929|r=-3}}}} today).<ref name="hageman"/> The portrait was the subject of considerable media attention and was written about in the February 12, 1929 edition of the ''[[New York Times]]'' and the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. It was later mentioned in various books about the Lincolns, including [[Carl Sandburg]]'s 1932 biography ''Mary Lincoln: Wife and Widow''.<ref name="cohen"/>
In 1976, [[Robert Todd Lincoln Beckwith]], the last undisputed Lincoln descendant, donated the portrait to the Illinois State Historical Library (now known as the [[Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum]]). At the time, the portrait was estimated to be worth $400,000 (approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|400000|1929|r=-3}}}} today). In 1978, art conservators at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] noted that the portrait had been "heavily retouched" and contained significant elements that were added after the original painting had been completed. After a partial [[Art restoration|restoration]], it was discovered that the facial area of the subject had been altered. The woman in the portrait was noted to have coloring that was brighter than the original 1929 portrait and that the face of the woman was "different, plainer" than Mary Todd Lincoln's.<ref name="cohen"/> The conservators also discovered that the subject was wearing a [[cross necklace]] which Mary Lincoln would not have worn as she was not a [[Roman Catholic]]. As the painting had been owned by the Lincoln family, the authenticity of the painting was not immediately questioned. The conservators that worked on the initial restoration reasoned that the added paint was likely the result of "heavy handed" retouches by other conservators or by Francis Bicknell Carpenter who was known to "fiddle with" his finished paintings.<ref name="wetterich3">{{cite web|url=http://www.galesburg.com/article/20120214/News/302149994/?Start=3|title=Fake Mary Todd painting makes it even more famous|last=Wetterich|first=Chris|date=February 14, 2012|publisher=galesburg.com|page=3|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> The lack of resemblance to the woman in the portrait to the real Mary Lincoln was rationalized as "artistic idealization". For the next 32 years, the portrait hung at the [[Illinois Executive Mansion]] in [[Springfield, Illinois]].<ref name="cohen"/>
In April 2010, art conservator Barry Bauman was hired to clean the portrait as it had accumulated dirt and grime after years of being displayed. Bauman also hoped to restore the portrait to its previous 1929 appearance. During the restoration, Bauman soon discovered that a layer of [[varnish]] sat on top of the paint indicating that someone had altered the original. After removing the varnish, Bauman discovered that the woman Bloom claimed was Mary Todd Lincoln was an unknown woman who bore no resemblance to the former First Lady. It was noted that the woman's coloring was "...much fresher, a much warmer, a much redder toned, flesh toned..." than the original painting depicted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.galesburg.com/article/20120214/News/302149994/?Start=1|title=Fake Mary Todd painting makes it even more famous|last=Wetterich|first=Chris|date=February 14, 2012|publisher=galesburg.com|pages=1–2|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> Bauman also discovered that a [[brooch]] bearing the face of Abraham Lincoln worn by the subject covered a floral brooch. Bauman also inspected the signature of Francis Bicknell Carpenter and the date, both of which were added on top of the varnish layer. After comparing the signature to Carpenter's other paintings, the signature was deemed a forgery.<ref name="wetterich2"/>
After the portrait was completely restored, Bauman determined that while it had been painted in the 1860s (likely around 1864), the woman in the portrait was not Mary Todd Lincoln and the painting was not the work of Francis Bicknell Carpenter. The real subject of the portrait and the artist remain unknown.<ref name="wetterich3"/> Bauman also determined that Bloom, who also painted his own works, had likely altered the original portrait himself. Bauman also believed Bloom painted over the original portrait, forged Carpenter's name and created the fake affidavit.<ref name="cohen"/> Bloom's claim that the portrait was given to his sister Susan by Jacob G. Neafie's daughter in appreciation of her care for the ailing Anna Neafie was proven to be false. Susan Bloom was born in 1855 and was only five years old when Anna Neafie died in 1860. James M. Cornelius, the curator of the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, believes that Bloom was able to pull off the hoax because all the participants in his story were dead. Cornelius also believes that Bloom sought the Lincolns out to not only make money from the sale of the portrait but to legitimatize its authenticity. Bloom was likely aware that the surviving Lincolns were eager to portray Mary and her son Robert Todd Lincoln in a more sympathetic light after the family had received a great deal of negative publicity after Robert had his mother forcibly institutionalized in 1875.<ref name="cohen"/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category}} * {{IBDB name}} * {{findagrave|85144618}} * [http://baumanconservation.com/TheDemiseofMaryLincolnfs.html Bauman, Barry. (Written 2011. Published February 10, 2012) Case Study: ''The Demise of Mary Lincoln: An Artistic Conspiracy'' Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum Collection file LR 938.]
{{authority control}}
